title: Slow-Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage Recipe
description: This slow cooker corned beef is a foolproof and delicious St. Patrick's Day dinner that cooks all day and lets you celebrate the easy way!

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Never lose a recipe:¬†Join MyRecipes to save and find favorites from AR & beyond Main Dishes Beef Corned Beef Recipes Corned Beef and Cabbage Recipes Slow-Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage 4.7 (2,068) 1,599 Reviews 241 Photos Cook this corned beef in a slow cooker all day, and you're guaranteed success ‚Äî no more dry corned beef! Serve with soda bread for a warm and satisfying Saint Patrick's Day dinner. Submitted by LUSYRSGIRL Updated on February 20, 2025 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 241 241 241 241 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 8 hrs Total Time: 8 hrs 15 mins Servings: 8 Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe This slow cooker corned beef and cabbage recipe is easy to prep in the morning and simmer all day in your crock pot ‚Äî you‚Äôll have a perfect Irish meal by dinnertime! How to Make Corned Beef and Cabbage In the Slow Cooker You'll find a detailed ingredient list and step-by-step instructions in the recipe below, but let's go over the basics: Slow Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage Ingredients These are the ingredients you‚Äôll need to make corned beef and cabbage in the slow cooker:¬† Vegetables: You‚Äôll need red potatoes, carrots, an onion, and, of course, cabbage.¬†Water: Cook the ingredients in four cups of water.¬†Corned beef: This recipe was written for use with a 4-pound corned beef brisket with a spice packet.¬†Beer: Beer lends irresistible flavor. How to Make Corned Beef and Cabbage In the Slow Cooker Here‚Äôs a brief overview of what you can expect when you make this crock pot corned beef and cabbage:¬† Place the potatoes, carrots, and onion in the slow cooker and add water.¬†Place the brisket on top of the vegetables, then pour the beer over the brisket.¬†Sprinkle the spice packet over the brisket and cook on High for 7 hours.Stir in the cabbage and cook for another hour.¬† Allrecipes What to Serve With Slow Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage Explore our entire collection of Irish Recipes for delicious serving inspiration. Here are a few of the ideas you‚Äôll find:¬† Amazingly Easy Irish Soda Bread Irish Boxty Diane's Colcannon Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise ‚ÄúEasy and delicious,‚Äù raves one Allrecipes community member. ‚ÄúI added more veggies to the recipe as my family eats a lot of them at all meals. I used Killian's Irish Red Beer.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is the best tasting corned beef dinner I‚Äôve ever made,‚Äù says Robin Miller. ‚ÄúMy guests raved about it too! Definitely a keeper!‚Äù ‚ÄúThis was the best recipe for corned beef and cabbage that I‚Äôve made so far,‚Äù according to Dee. ‚ÄúThe potatoes, carrots and cabbage were so full of flavor. I‚Äôll definitely make this again.‚Äù Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings 10 baby red potatoes, quartered 4 large carrots, peeled and cut into matchstick pieces 1 onion, peeled and cut into bite-sized pieces 4 cups water 1 (4 pound) corned beef brisket with spice packet 6 ounces beer ¬Ω head cabbage, coarsely chopped Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place potatoes, carrots, and onion into the bottom of a slow cooker; add water and place brisket on top of vegetables. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Pour beer over brisket; sprinkle over spices from the packet and cover. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cook on High for 7 hours; stir in the cabbage and cook for 1 more hour. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Cook‚Äôs Note Opt for a dark beer, such as a Guinness or another dry Irish stout, for the best flavor.¬† I Made It Print 5,319 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 473 Calories 20g Fat 50g Carbs 24g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 8 Calories 473 % Daily Value * Total Fat 20g 25% Saturated Fat 7g 33% Cholesterol 100mg 33% Sodium 1281mg 56% Total Carbohydrate 50g 18% Dietary Fiber 7g 24% Total Sugars 7g Protein 24g 47% Vitamin C 55mg 61% Calcium 68mg 5% Iron 3mg 17% Potassium 1126mg 24% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Slow-Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage 01 of 241 Photo by¬† Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 241 Photo by¬† Brian 03/17/2025 Great flavors Fantastic recipe. I did not put the slow cooker on high. I put it on low for 8 hours. Everything was perfect. 03 of 241 Photo by¬† DaringMug4531 03/17/2025 A keeper! Just put in the slow cooker. I'm praying it will turn out delicious! 04 of 241 Photo by¬† PoliteGlass6778 03/18/2024 A keeper! Worth the effort Made it! Wonderful and the Murphy & Davids brand of corned beef I got from Texas based HEB grocery was not salty at all...actually added salt...lol..I used same amount of water and more beer just because what am I gonna do with the rest of the can since I don't really drink beer and quite frankly it took all that liquid to fully cover the brisket as recommended on other recipes. I added half the red potatoes & carrots to the bottom at the start. Chopped big to avoid mush. I did 4 hours on high, took the cabbage wedges out then added the rest of potatoes, carrots and cabbage wedges. At this point I moved and tried to keep most of the veggies on top since I feared mushy veggies. Cooked for about 3 more hours on high. I meant to turn to low for an hour but later discovered I had turn it off. Lol. I checked the meat and it was pull apart tender so I decided not to turn it back on. I let the residual heat and steam do the rest. 05 of 241 Photo by¬† Marion 03/17/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Absolutely spectacular! I have never had luck making corned beef & cabbage, to the point we switched to ham & cabbage. I decided to give it another try with this recipe and the only complaint was there wasn‚Äôt any more. I followed the recipe exactly, except I used Mich Ultra and salt free beef broth‚Ä¶no water. Some of the reviews said to cut it back to low and add the potatoes & carrots, then turn it up to high the last hour when I added the cabbage. This is the absolute best recipe and definitely a keeper! 06 of 241 Photo by¬† CleverOats5792 03/17/2024 Trying this recipe for the first time . We shall see üáÆüá™üòÉ. I will post my results when done for sure !! 07 of 241 Photo by¬† HeartyUdon5094 10/22/2023 Absolutely a game-changer. This was try #3 to make the best corned beef. The first two times, we tried different recipes and both came out dry, tough and salty. This one absolutely melts in your mouth. All I can do is plead with all fellow doubters to TRUST, TRUST, TRUST. High temp is NOT crazy. 8 hours is NOT too long. Guinness Extra Stout is NOT too strong. Water is NOT the wrong liquid. Vegetables will NOT be mush (just cut them larger to ensure it). To the top of the meat, we added all the spices called for (except salt) as if we were pre-brining the meat ourselves (peppercorns, juniper berries, pickling spice, caraway seed, garlic, ground cloves, bay leaves, etc.). Cut with the grain, it falls apart in beautiful shreds. Cut against the grain, it melts in your mouth. 08 of 241 Photo by¬† Terri 04/02/2023 I made it using Budweiser beer and I cooked it on low for 8 hours. I felt the low allowed the meat to become softer and the vegetables to be tastier. I really cook anything on high in the Crock-Pot especially meats. But did enjoy it 09 of 241 Photo by¬† Sarah Jo Cross 02/26/2023 Perfect and delicious! I used a skunky beer, and 2 cups of hot beef broth (added when adding the potatoes). Cooked the brisket on low 7 hours, potatoes for 4 hours and halved Brussel spouts for 2 hours. 10 of 241 Photo by¬† vicki936 03/22/2022 Used a 3.5 lb flat corned beef brisket from HEB - Murphy & David's corned beef brisket1 1.5 lb bag of baby red potatoes, halved (entire bag)1 onion, sliced thickly and placed in the bottom first4 thick carrots, cut into large chunkshalf can of Shiner Bockfollowed recipe to a T - set crockpot on High for 8 hrs.chopped cabbage and added after 7 hoursMeat was good, not falling apart and I was able to slice. Did not really like the flavor of the broth and veggies. Might like better using beef broth instead of beer. Made a sweet mustard sauce and Irish soda bread to go with it and used the leftovers to make sandwiches the next couple of days. Good economical meals. The mustard sauce saved it for me! 1 2 3 4 5 Next You‚Äôll Also Love Corned Beef and Cabbage with Guinness¬Æ-Dijon Gravy 5 Ratings Slow Cooker Guinness Corned Beef and Veggies 172 Ratings Corned Beef and Cabbage 1,424 Ratings Easy Corned Beef and Cabbage 213 Ratings Sarah's Slow-Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage 24 Ratings Instant Pot Corned Beef 229 Ratings Grandma's Canned Corned Beef and Cabbage Soup 1 Rating Apple and Brown Sugar Corned Beef 208 Ratings Instant Pot Guinness Corned Beef 32 Ratings St. Patrick's Colcannon 39 Ratings Sous Vide Corned Beef 4 Ratings Shepherd's Pie 3,281 Ratings Braised Corned Beef Brisket 1,057 Ratings Corned Beef Irish Feast 19 Ratings Dutch Oven Corned Beef and Cabbage 259 Ratings Corned Beef and Cabbage 217 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices ¬† Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith¬†publishing¬†family.
